title: Shirahoshi as Ancient Weapon Poseidon
summary: Theory that Shirahoshi is the current incarnation of the Ancient Weapon Poseidon, with the ability to command Sea Kings, a power that awakens in certain members of the royal family every 100 years.
fullText: Shirahoshi is revealed to be the Ancient Weapon Poseidon, possessing the hereditary ability to command Sea Kings. This power only manifests in female members of the Ryugu Kingdom's royal family approximately once per century. Queen Otohime was aware of this fearsome ability and knew that if Shirahoshi received a huge shock, she might subconsciously send Sea Kings on a rampage. Otohime described this as the most fearsome ability in the world that can change the whole world in great ways, but in the wrong hands, could sink the entire world into the ocean. According to legend, Shirahoshi will receive a visit from an unknown person responsible for guiding her power on the right path, at which time the world will experience profound upheavals.
author: One Piece Community

title: Hody Jones as Pure Evil - The Monster Created by Stories
summary: Theory and analysis that Hody Jones represents 'pure evil' born from secondhand hatred, embodying racism without personal experience of harm from humans.
fullText: Hody Jones is unique among One Piece villains as a representation of baseless hatred and inherited racism. When asked what humans did to him that led to his extreme actions, Hody's answer was simply 'Nothing' - he was racist purely because of stories he heard from others. Unlike Arlong who experienced slavery and discrimination firsthand, Hody hated humans without any real interaction with them. He was influenced by Arlong's teachings and the environment of the Fish-Man District, becoming the perfect representation of how prejudice perpetuates through generations without requiring direct personal harm. Author Eiichiro Oda created Hody Jones as a tool to help fans understand racism and its impact on groups of people. Hody is a manifestation of racism and a willing participant in a cycle of hatred he hoped would never end, making him one of the most terrifying villains because his evil has no tragic backstory to explain it - it's purely ideological.
author: One Piece Community Analysis

source.title: Why Hody Jones is one of the greatest villains in the One Piece franchise

title: Queen Otohime's Ideals Living On
summary: Theory that Queen Otohime's dream of peace between humans and fish-men will ultimately succeed through Shirahoshi and Luffy's actions, fulfilling the prophecy of Poseidon's guide.
fullText: Despite Queen Otohime's assassination ten years before the Straw Hats' arrival, her ideals for peaceful coexistence between humans and fish-men continue to influence Fish-Man Island. As Jinbe states, 'Even after her death, no one has forgotten her ideals.' The theory suggests that Luffy represents the prophesied guide who will help Shirahoshi use her power as Poseidon on the right path. By helping Shirahoshi leave her tower and visit her mother's grave, Luffy is already beginning to fulfill this role. The emotional connection between Shirahoshi's first visit to her mother's grave and her eventual role in changing the world represents the continuation of Otohime's dream. This theory connects to the larger One Piece theme of inherited will - Otohime's will is being inherited not just by her children, but by those who believe in her vision of a better world.
author: One Piece Theorists

title: Generational Conflict: Hachi vs. Hody
summary: Analysis theory that the confrontation between Hachi and Hody represents the conflict between those who learn from the past versus those who repeat it.
fullText: Episode 534's confrontation between Hachi and Hody Jones represents a critical thematic element: the generational divide in how fish-men respond to historical oppression. Hachi, who once served Arlong and believed in fish-man supremacy, has been redeemed through positive interactions with humans (particularly the Straw Hats). He now actively opposes the ideology he once supported. In contrast, Hody represents the younger generation that has taken the teachings of hatred and radicalized them further without ever experiencing the actual oppression that fueled Arlong's anger. This makes Hody both more dangerous (because he's calculated and patient) and more pathetic (because his hatred is entirely secondhand). The theory suggests this conflict mirrors real-world generational cycles of prejudice, where hatred can intensify even as direct experience of harm diminishes. Hachi's willingness to sacrifice himself to stop Hody represents the hope that the cycle can be broken.
author: Never Watched One Piece Blog
